thread.title: Tanzania: Experts Tout Green Investments

title: Tanzania: Experts Tout Green Investments
text:
Tanzania: PLWHAs Seek Support for Their Economic Projects 
Mr Andersen said his company's forest conservation project with communities in Manyara region prevents deforestation of an estimated 350 hectares per annum which sequestrates 30,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide. 
"Our investment in forest conservation leads to the exact outcomes that the report identifies, which is delivering biodiversity conservation that supports local livelihoods, regulating water services provision to local people and livestock, creating localised economic activity that leads to enhanced incomes for local community members and therefore contribute directly to poverty alleviation," Andersen said. 
He noted that with an impending global agreement on Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD+), local communities which are responsible for conserving natural forests will earn money to improve their lives. 
"As mentioned above, the payments we make directly contribute to poverty alleviation, and the certification under which we operate demands that economic benefits accrue to the communities who participate in the REDD activities. 
By providing payment to the communities, many aspects of environmental destruction are avoided as people have income that allows them to choose good forest governance over degradation and deforestation as a source of income," the Carbon Tanzania spokesperson noted. 
Carbon Tanzania paid two little known Hadzabe villages of Arusha Region and earned 38m/- being payment for their forests carbon sequestration last year. Carbon Tanzania said in a report on its website that the two villages, Domanga and Mongo wa Mono successfully kept deforestation at bay using traditional patrol guards known as Walinzi wa Jadi. 
"Of the 38m/- paid by Carbon Tanzania to Domanga and Mongo wa Mono villages in the first half of 2014, 7.2m/- was paid directly to the Walinzi wa Jadi using M Pesa, both creating employment and ensuring patrolling and enforcement of the project area," Carbon Tanzania said in a report. 
The Arusha based company whose operations this year have focused on monitoring, financial planning and preparing the way for project expansion, said the Hadzabe have contained land conflicts which poaching remains a minor problem. 
"Our monthly monitoring systems are essential to allow us to understand the situation on the ground and document land incursions, political discourse and poaching events. 
The anti-poaching and data gathering teams, or Walinzi wa Jadi, patrol within the 20,200ha project area, the core area for the Hadzabe to utilise," the company noted. 
Whilst poaching incidents continue to occur, those involving weapons declined from seven in mid 2013 to zero in mid 2014, this excellent result is due mainly to a number of arrests made by the Walinzi Wajadi supported by the district game officer and Ujamaa Community Resource Team (UCRT), the report added. 
Carbon Tanzania which works in partnership with UCRT and Dorobo Safaris Limited to strengthen accountability and refine how money reaches the community and how it is spent, pointed out that several clients especially tour operating and travel companies are paying to offset carbon footprint of tourists. 
"Along with Dorobo Safaris and Haydom Lutheran Hospital we have set up a dedicated heath fund for the Hadzabe which allows individuals to obtain free medical treatment from the hospital," the report noted. 
Commenting on the same report, Dr Kilahama who is also Chairman of board of trustees of Mpingo Conservation and Development Initiative said it's high time that global leaders strike a deal on carbon trading during the forthcoming Paris Climate Change Summit. 
"Initially we thought carbon credits would save the environment by being an incentive to the farmers to conserve and manage the forest properly. But this hoe is fading away after seeing that the negotiations since 2007 (in Bali Indonesia) until today have not been fruitful," Dr Kilahama lamented. 
He warned that increasingly, selling carbon credits is becoming a business entity other than being a service to enhancing environmental stability. 
"In addition to that the capacity of villagers to handle own situation is low hence, destruction of forests is rampant when global communities had thought to keep the forests and woodlands intact and through REDD+ financial support to poor and developing countries to enhance the protection of forests and woodlands would have been provided," Dr Kilahama pointed out. 
The retired Director of Forestry and Beekeping and Ministry of Natural Resources and Tourism further lamented that after eight years of global negotiations, nothing concrete has been attained and worse still the language has changed from support and incentives to local communities to enable then protect and manage the forests and woodlands properly to performance base carbon credit payments and, or technical and financial support. 
"Since it is taking too long for the global community to reach an legally binding agreement on the matter through the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC); it is doubtful in carbon credits will be beneficial to Tanzania and other developing countries," he observed. 
The UNEP report titled, 'Investing in Forestry Sector Can Reverse Estimated US$3.5 Billion Economic Drain of Deforestation, Alleviate Poverty in Tanzania,' released last month said deforestation in the country could cost the national economy over 5.5bn/- based on 2013 exchange rates) between 2013 and 2033. 
"Forest ecosystems in the transition to a green economy and the role of REDD+ in the United Republic of Tanzania took into account the market value of timber resources as benefits that arise from deforestation, and costs in terms of lost timber forest products in the future, as well as other forest ecosystem services that will be lost as a result of deforestation," the report stated.
